info.name: Intro to Writing Tests
info.description:
# About this collection

Postman's powerful scripting feature helps you to write a range of API tests in JavaScript, including integration, regression, and contract tests.

## Using the collection

**Step 1:** Send the sample requests and view the response and test results.

**Step 2:** Replace the sample request URLs with your desired API endpoints.

**Step 3:** Customize the tests in the "Tests" tab if needed. Don't forget to save your changes.

## Quick tips for writing tests

- Organize your test scenarios by grouping your requests in [collections](https://www.getpostman.com/docs/v6/postman/collections/intro_to_collections) and [folders](https://www.getpostman.com/docs/v6/postman/collections/managing_collections#adding-folders), and naming them descriptively
- Document your APIâ€™s requirements using [markdown in the descriptions](https://www.getpostman.com/docs/v6/postman/collections/using_markdown_for_descriptions)
- Use [variables](https://www.getpostman.com/docs/v6/postman/environments_and_globals/variables) to simulate more sophisticated user flows
- Common tests that will be run after every request can be added to collection-level tests or folder-level tests
    

## Resources

[Test scripts](https://www.getpostman.com/docs/v6/postman/scripts/test_scripts)

[Test examples](https://www.getpostman.com/docs/v6/postman/scripts/test_examples)

[Quick reference guide](https://community.getpostman.com/t/the-postman-cheatsheet-quick-reference-guide/1054)

[Examples and guides](https://github.com/DannyDainton/All-Things-Postman)

[Writing tests in Postman](http://blog.getpostman.com/2017/10/25/writing-tests-in-postman/)

[API testing tips from a Postman professional](http://blog.getpostman.com/2017/07/28/api-testing-tips-from-a-postman-professional/)

item.name: Basic test syntax

exec: // use the `pm.*` API to write your test
// the first parameter is the name of your test (be descriptive)
// the second parameter is a function whereby if any assertions within your function fail, then the test will fail
pm.test("Name of the first test", function () {
// if your assertion throws an error, this test will fail
pm.test("Name of the second test", function () {
// make as many assertions as you'd like as part of this test
// if any assertion throws an error, this test will fail
// Note the difference in the test failure message under the **Test Results** tab when using pm.response vs. pm.expect
// Using a 2nd optional parameter with the pm.expect function to create a custom error message
pm.test("Using a custom error message", function () {

item.description:
This folder helps you understand how to work with the [Postman Sandbox](https://www.getpostman.com/docs/v6/postman/scripts/postman_sandbox), a JavaScript execution environment that is accessible during pre-request scripts and test scripts.

Whatever code you write under the pre-request and test tabs is executed in this sandbox.

Any code that you write under the "Tests" tab, in the Postman app will execute after your request.

Consequently, you have access to the `pm.response` object to make assertions against the actual response -- this is what we call a Postman test.

Review the example tests under the "Tests" tab.

> **Quick tips for syntax** 
  

- Give each test a descriptive name. When the test fails, this will provide context to the error.
- Use `pm.response()` as your base assertion where possible to provide more descriptive error messages.
- Use the optional 2nd parameter in `pm.expect()` to create custom error messages.

exec: //   pm.expect(tv4.validate(data2, schema)).to.be.true; // this statement would not be true

request.description:
This test is written to validate that response payloads returned from the server are well-formed. It uses the [Tiny Validator for JSON Schema v4](http://geraintluff.github.io/tv4/).

The Postman sandbox offers a built-in tv4 validator to simplify your assertions. Use [JSON-schema](http://json-schema.org/) [draft v4](http://json-schema.org/latest/json-schema-core.html) to validate simple values and complex objects using a rich [validation vocabulary](http://json-schema.org/latest/json-schema-validation.html) ([examples](http://json-schema.org/examples.html)).

urlencoded.description:
String query = "SELECT account_balance FROM user_data WHERE user_name = "
   + request.getParameter("customerName");
Probably best not to do this one in production, or at all, except for demonstration purposes

request.description: This test checks if it is possible to inject malicious strings as a request parameter. If your server is not handling user input properly, these strings can be interpreted by your server as SQL commands that result in leaking sensitive information or general mayhem.

urlencoded.description:

   + request.getParameter("customerName");
Probably best not to do this one in production, or at all, except for demonstration purposes

item.description:
This folder contains examples of testing a single HTTP API request.

In the Postman app, under the "Tests" tab for each request, notice the test(s) written to validate specific assertions. Some of these tests are available as a "Snippet" on the right sidebar.

Send each request to see the results under the "Test Results" tab in the response viewer.
